text: There was a man in the land of Uz called Job, and this man was an upright and just man, one that feared God, and eschewed evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he had seven sons, and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: His substance also was seven thousand sheep, and three thousand camels, and five hundred yoke of oxen, and five hundred she asses, and his family was very great, so that this man was the greatest of all the men of the East.
speaker: Narrator

text: And his sons went and banqueted in their houses, every one his day, and sent, and called their three sisters to eat and to drink with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the days of their banqueting were gone about, Job sent, and sanctified them, and rose up early in the morning, and offered burnt offerings according to the number of them all. For Job thought, It may be that my sons have sinned, and blasphemed God in their hearts, thus did Job every day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now on a day when the children of God came and stood before the Lord, Satan came also among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said unto Satan, Whence comest thou? And Satan answered the Lord, saying, From compassing the earth to and fro, and from walking in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said unto Satan, Hast thou not considered my servant Job, how none is like him in the earth? an upright and just man, one that feareth God, and escheweth evil?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Satan answered the Lord, and said, Doth Job fear God for nought?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou not made an hedge about him and about his house, and about all that he hath on every side? thou hast blessed the work of his hands, and his substance is increased in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But stretch out now thine hand and touch all that he hath, to see if he will not blaspheme thee to thy face.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said unto Satan, Lo, all that he hath is in thine hand: only upon himself shalt thou not stretch out thine hand. So Satan departed from the presence of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on a day, when his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother’s house,
speaker: Narrator

text: There came a messenger unto Job, and said, The oxen were plowing, and the asses feeding in their places,
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Sabeans came violently, and took them: yea, they have slain the servants with the edge of the sword: but I only am escaped alone to tell thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: And while he was yet speaking, another came, and said, The fire of God is fallen from the heaven, and hath burnt up the sheep and the servants, and devoured them: but I only am escaped alone to tell thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: And while he was yet speaking, another came, and said, The Chaldeans set on three bands, and fell upon the camels, and have taken them, and have slain the servants with the edge of the sword: but I only am escaped alone to tell thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: And while he was yet speaking, came another, and said, Thy sons, and thy daughters were eating, and drinking wine in their eldest brother’s house,
speaker: Narrator

text: And behold, there came a great wind from beyond the wilderness, and smote the four corners of the house, which fell upon the children, and they are dead, and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job arose, and rent his garment, and shaved his head, and fell down upon the ground, and worshipped,
speaker: Narrator

text: And said, Naked came I out of my mother’s womb, and naked shall I return thither: the Lord hath given, and the Lord hath taken it: blessed be the Name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all this did not Job sin, nor charge God foolishly.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on a day the children of God came and stood before the Lord, and Satan came also among them, and stood before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said unto Satan, Whence comest thou? And Satan answered the Lord, and said, From compassing the earth to and fro, and from walking in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said unto Satan, Hast thou not considered my servant Job, how none is like him in the earth? an upright and just man, one that feareth God, and escheweth evil? for yet he continueth in his uprightness, although thou movedst me against him, to destroy him without cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Satan answered the Lord, and said, Skin for skin, and all that ever a man hath, will he give for his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: But stretch now out thine hand, and touch his bones and his flesh, to see if he will not blaspheme thee to thy face.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said unto Satan, Lo, he is in thine hand, but save his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Satan departed from the presence of the Lord, and smote Job with sore boils, from the sole of his foot unto his crown.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he took a potsherd to scrape him, and he sat down among the ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then said his wife unto him, Dost thou continue yet in thine uprightness? Blaspheme God, and die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said unto her, Thou speakest like a foolish woman: what? shall we receive good at the hand of God, and not receive evil? In all this did not Job sin with his lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Job’s three friends heard of all this evil that was come upon him, they came every one from his own place, to wit, Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite: for they were agreed together to come to lament with him, and to comfort him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when they lifted up their eyes afar off, they knew him not: therefore they lifted up their voices and wept, and every one of them rent his garment and sprinkled dust upon their heads toward the heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sat by him upon the ground seven days, and seven nights, and none spake a word unto him: for they saw that the grief was very great.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward Job opened his mouth, and cursed his day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job cried out, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the day perish wherein I was born, and the night when it was said, There is a man child conceived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let that day be darkness, let not God regard it from above, neither let the light shine upon it,
speaker: Narrator

text: But let darkness and the shadow of death stain it: let the cloud remain upon it, and let them make it fearful as a bitter day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let darkness possess that night, let it not be joined unto the days of the year, nor let it come into the count of the months.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, desolate be that night, and let no joy be in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them that curse the day, (being ready to renew their mourning) curse it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the stars of that twilight be dim through darkness of it: let it look for light, but have none: neither let it see the dawning of the day,
speaker: Narrator

text: Because it shut not up the doors of my mother’s womb, nor hid sorrow from mine eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why died I not in the birth? or why died I not, when I came out of the womb?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did the knees prevent me? and why did I suck the breasts?
speaker: Narrator

text: For so should I now have lain and been quiet, I should have slept then, and been at rest,
speaker: Narrator

text: With the kings and counselors of the earth, which have built themselves desolate places:
speaker: Narrator

text: Or with the princes that had gold, and have filled their houses with silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or why was I not hid, as an untimely birth, either as infants, which have not seen the light?
speaker: Narrator

text: The wicked have there ceased from their tyranny, and there they that labored valiantly, are at rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prisoners rest together, and hear not the voice of the oppressor.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are small and great, and the servant is free from his master.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore is the light given to him that is in misery? and life unto them that have heavy hearts?
speaker: Narrator

text: Which long for death, and if it come not, they would even search it more than treasures:
speaker: Narrator

text: Which joy for gladness, and rejoice, when they can find the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why is the light given to the man whose way is hid, and whom God hath hedged in?
speaker: Narrator

text: For my sighing cometh before I eat, and my roarings are poured out like the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the thing I feared, is come upon me, and the thing that I was afraid of, is come unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I had no peace, neither had I quietness, neither had I rest, yet trouble is come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite, answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: If we assay to commune with thee, wilt thou be grieved? but who can withhold himself from speaking?
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, thou hast taught many, and hast strengthened the weary hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy words have confirmed him that was falling, and thou hast strengthened the weak knees.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now it is come upon thee, and thou art grieved: it toucheth thee, and thou art troubled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not this thy fear, thy confidence, thy patience, and uprightness of thy ways?
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember, I pray thee: who ever perished, being an innocent? or where were the upright destroyed?
speaker: Narrator

text: As I have seen, they that plow iniquity, and sow wickedness, reap the same.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the blast of God they perish, and with the breath of his nostrils are they consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roaring of the Lion, and the voice of the Lioness, and the teeth of the Lion’s whelps are broken.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lion perisheth for lack of prey, and the Lion’s whelps are scattered abroad.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a thing was brought to me secretly, and mine ear hath received a little thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thoughts of the visions of the night, when sleep falleth on men,
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear came upon me, and dread which made all my bones to tremble.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the wind passed before me, and made the hairs of my flesh to stand up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then stood one, and I knew not his face: an image was before mine eyes, and in silence heard I a voice, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shall man be more just than God? or shall a man be more pure than his Maker?
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, he found no steadfastness in his servants, and laid folly upon his Angels.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much more in them that dwell in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust, which shall be destroyed before the moth?
speaker: Narrator

text: They be destroyed from the morning unto the evening: they perish forever, without regard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth not their dignity go away with them? do they not die, and that without wisdom?
speaker: Narrator

text: Call now, if any will answer thee, and to which of the Saints wilt thou turn?
speaker: Narrator

text: Doubtless anger killeth the foolish, and envy slayeth the idiot.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have seen the foolish well rooted, and suddenly I cursed his habitation, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: His children shall be far from salvation, and they shall be destroyed in the gate, and none shall deliver them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hungry shall eat up his harvest: yea, they shall take it from among the thorns, and the thirsty shall drink up their substance.
speaker: Narrator

text: For misery cometh not forth of the dust, neither doeth affliction spring out of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But man is born unto travail, as the sparks fly upward.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I would inquire at God, and turn my talk unto God:
speaker: Narrator

text: Which doeth great things, and unsearchable, and marvelous things without number.
speaker: Narrator

text: He giveth rain upon the earth, and poureth water upon the streets,
speaker: Narrator

text: And setteth up on high them that be low, that the sorrowful may be exalted to salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text: He scattereth the devices of the crafty: so that their hands cannot accomplish that which they do enterprise.
speaker: Narrator

text: He taketh the wise in their craftiness, and the counsel of the wicked is made foolish.
speaker: Narrator

text: They meet with darkness in the daytime, and grope at noonday, as in the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he saveth the poor from the sword, from their mouth, and from the hand of the violent man,
speaker: Narrator

text: So that the poor hath his hope, but iniquity shall stop her mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, blessed is the man whom God correcteth: therefore refuse not thou the chastising of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he maketh the wound, and bindeth it up: he smiteth, and his hands make whole.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall deliver thee in six troubles, and in the seventh the evil shall not touch thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: In famine he shall deliver thee from death: and in battle from the power of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou shalt be hid from the scourge of the tongue, and thou shalt not be afraid of destruction when it cometh.
speaker: Narrator

text: But thou shalt laugh at destruction and dearth, and shalt not be afraid of the beast of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the stones of the field shall be in league with thee, and the beasts of the field shall be at peace with thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: And thou shalt know, that peace shall be in thy tabernacle, and thou shalt visit thine habitation, and shalt not sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou shalt perceive also that thy seed shall be great, and thy posterity as the grass of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou shalt go to thy grave in a full age, as a rick of corn cometh in due season into the barn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, thus have we inquired of it, and so it is: hear this and know it for thyself.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Job answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Oh that my grief were well weighed, and my miseries were laid together in the balance!
speaker: Narrator

text: For it would be now heavier than the sand of the sea: therefore my words are swallowed up.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the arrows of the Almighty are in me, the venom whereof doth drink up my spirit, and the terrors of God fight against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth the wild ass bray when he hath grass? or loweth the ox when he hath fodder?
speaker: Narrator

text: That which is unsavory, shall it be eaten without salt? or is there any taste in the white of an egg?
speaker: Narrator

text: Such things as my soul refused to touch, as were sorrows, are my meat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Oh that I might have my desire, and that God would grant me the thing that I long for!
speaker: Narrator

text: That is, that God would destroy me: that he would let his hand go, and cut me off.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then should I yet have comfort, (though I burn with sorrow, let him not spare) because I have not denied the words of the Holy one.
speaker: Narrator

text: What power have I that I should endure? or what is mine end, if I should prolong my life?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is my strength the strength of stones? or is my flesh of brass?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it not so, that there is in me no help? and that strength is taken from me?
speaker: Narrator

text: He that is in misery, ought to be comforted of his neighbor: but men have forsaken the fear of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brethren have deceived me as a brook, and as the rising of the rivers they pass away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Which are blackish with ice, and wherein the snow is hid.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in time they are dried up with heat and are consumed: and when it is hot they fail out of their places,
speaker: Narrator

text: Or they depart from their way and course, yea, they vanish and perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: They that go to Tema, considered them, and they that go to Sheba, waited for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they were confounded: when they hoped, they came thither, and were ashamed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely now are ye like unto it: ye have seen my fearful plague, and are afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Was it because I said, Bring unto me? or give a reward to me of your substance?
speaker: Narrator

text: And deliver me from the enemy’s hand, or ransom me out of the hand of tyrants?
speaker: Narrator

text: Teach me, and I will hold my tongue: and cause me to understand, wherein I have erred.
speaker: Narrator

text: How steadfast are the words of righteousness? and what can any of you justly reprove?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do ye imagine to reprove words, that the talk of the afflicted should be as the wind?
speaker: Narrator

text: Ye make your wrath to fall upon the fatherless, and dig a pit for your friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore be content to look upon me: for I will not lie before your face.
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn, I pray you, let there be none iniquity: return, I say, and ye shall see yet my righteousness in that behalf. Is there iniquity in my tongue? doth not my mouth feel sorrows?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is there not an appointed time to man upon earth? and are not his days as the days of an hireling?
speaker: Narrator

text: As a servant longeth for the shadow, and as an hireling looketh for the end of his work,
speaker: Narrator

text: So have I had as an inheritance the months of vanity, and painful nights have been appointed unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I laid me down, I said, When shall I arise? and measuring the evening, I am even full with tossing to and fro unto the dawning of the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: My flesh is clothed with worms and filthiness of the dust: my skin is rent, and become horrible.
speaker: Narrator

text: My days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle, and they are spent without hope.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that my life is but a wind, and that mine eye shall not return to see pleasure.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eye that hath seen me, shall see me no more: thine eyes are upon me, and I shall be no longer.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the cloud vanisheth and goeth away, so he that goeth down to the grave, shall come up no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall return no more to his house, neither shall his place know him anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I will not spare my mouth, but will speak in the trouble of my spirit, and muse in the bitterness of my mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Am I a sea or a whalefish, that thou keepest me in ward?
speaker: Narrator

text: When I say, My couch shall relieve me, and my bed shall bring comfort in my meditation,
speaker: Narrator

text: Then fearest thou me with dreams, and astonishest me with visions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore my soul chooseth rather to be strangled and to die, than to be in my bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: I abhor it: I shall not live always: spare me then, for my days are but vanity.
speaker: Narrator

text: What is man, that thou dost magnify him, and that thou settest thine heart upon him?
speaker: Narrator

text: And dost visit him every morning, and triest him every moment?
speaker: Narrator

text: How long will it be ere thou depart from me? thou wilt not let me alone while I may swallow my spittle.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have sinned, what shall I do unto thee? O thou preserver of men, why hast thou set me as a mark against thee, so that I am a burden unto myself?
speaker: Narrator

text: And why dost thou not pardon my trespass? and take away mine iniquity? for now shall I sleep in the dust, and if thou seek me in the morning, I shall not be found.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: How long wilt thou talk of these things? and how long shall the words of thy mouth be as a mighty wind?
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth God pervert judgment? or doth the Almighty subvert justice?
speaker: Narrator

text: If thy sons have sinned against him, and he hath sent them into the place of their iniquity,
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet if thou wilt early seek unto God, and pray to the Almighty,
speaker: Narrator

text: If thou be pure and upright, then surely he will awake up unto thee, and he will make the habitation of thy righteousness prosperous.
speaker: Narrator

text: And though thy beginning be small, yet thy latter end shall greatly increase.
speaker: Narrator

text: Inquire therefore, I pray thee, of the former age, and prepare thyself to search of their fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: (For we are but of yesterday, and are ignorant: for our days upon earth are but a shadow)
speaker: Narrator

text: Shall not they teach thee and tell thee, and utter the words of their heart?
speaker: Narrator

text: Can a rush grow without mire? or can the grass grow without water?
speaker: Narrator

text: Though it were in green and not cut down, yet shall it wither before any other herb.
speaker: Narrator

text: So are the paths of all that forget God, and the hypocrite’s hope shall perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: His confidence also shall be cut off, and his trust shall be as the house of a spider.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall lean upon his house, but it shall not stand: he shall hold him fast by it, yet shall it not endure.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tree is green before the Sun, and the branches spread over the garden thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roots thereof are wrapped about the fountain, and are folded about the house of stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any pluck it from his place, and it deny, saying, I have not seen thee,
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, it will rejoice by this means, that it may grow in another mold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, God will not cast away an upright man, neither will he take the wicked by the hand,
speaker: Narrator

text: Till he have filled thy mouth with laughter, and thy lips with joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: They that hate thee, shall be clothed with shame, and the dwelling of the wicked shall not remain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: I know verily that it is so: for how should man compared unto God, be justified?
speaker: Narrator

text: If he would dispute with him, he could not answer him one thing of thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is wise in heart, and mighty in strength: who hath been fierce against him, and hath prospered?
speaker: Narrator

text: He removeth the mountains, and they feel not when he overthroweth them in his wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text: He removeth the earth out of her place, that the pillars thereof do shake.
speaker: Narrator

text: He commandeth the Sun, and it riseth not: he closeth up the stars, as under a signet.
speaker: Narrator

text: He himself alone spreadeth out the heavens, and walketh upon the height of the Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: He maketh the stars Arcturus, Orion, and Pleiades, and the climates of the South.
speaker: Narrator

text: He doeth great things, and unsearchable: yea, marvelous things without number.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, when he goeth by me, I see him not: and when he passeth by, I perceive him not:
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, when he taketh a prey, who can make him to restore it? who shall say unto him, What doest thou?
speaker: Narrator

text: God will not withdraw his anger, and the most mighty helpers do stoop under him.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much less shall I answer him? or how should I find out my words with him?
speaker: Narrator

text: For though I were just, yet could I not answer, but I would make supplication to my Judge.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I cry, and he answer me, yet would I not believe, that he heard my voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he destroyeth me with a tempest, and woundeth me without cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will not suffer me to take my breath, but filleth me with bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we speak of strength, behold, he is strong: if we speak of judgment, who shall bring me in to plead?
speaker: Narrator

text: If I should justify myself, mine own mouth shall condemn me: if I would be perfect, he shall judge me wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though I were perfect, yet I know not my soul: therefore abhor I my life.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is one point: therefore I said, He destroyeth the perfect and the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the scourge should suddenly slay, should God laugh at the punishment of the innocent?
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth is given into the hand of the wicked: he covereth the faces of the judges thereof: if not, where is he? or who is he?
speaker: Narrator

text: My days have been more swift than a post: they have fled, and have seen no good thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are passed as with the most swift ships, and as the Eagle that flieth to the prey.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I say, I will forget my complaint, I will cease from my wrath, and comfort me,
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I am afraid of all my sorrows, knowing that thou wilt not judge me innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I be wicked, why labor I thus in vain?
speaker: Narrator

text: If I wash myself with snow water, and purge mine hands most clean,
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet shalt thou plunge me in the pit, and mine own clothes shall make me filthy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he is not a man as I am, that I should answer him, if we come together to judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither is there any umpire that might lay his hand upon us both.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let him take his rod away from me, and let not his fear astonish me:
speaker: Narrator

text: Then will I speak, and fear him not: but because I am not so, I hold me still.
speaker: Narrator

text: My soul is cut off though I live: I will leave my complaint upon myself, and will speak in the bitterness of my soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will say unto God, Condemn me not: show me, wherefore thou contendest with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thinkest thou it good to oppress me, and to cast off the labor of thine hands, and to favor the counsel of the wicked?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou carnal eyes? or dost thou see as man seeth?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are thy days as man’s days? or thy years as the time of man,
speaker: Narrator

text: That thou inquirest of mine iniquity, and searchest out my sin?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou knowest that I cannot do wickedly: for none can deliver me out of thine hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thine hands have made me, and fashioned me wholly round about, and wilt thou destroy me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember, I pray thee, that thou hast made me as the clay, and wilt thou bring me into dust again?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou not poured me out as milk? and turned me to curds like cheese?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast clothed me with skin and flesh, and joined me together with bones and sinews.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast given me life, and grace: and the visitation hath preserved my spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though thou hast hid these things in thine heart, yet I know that it is so with thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I have sinned, then thou wilt straightly look unto me, and wilt not hold me guiltless of mine iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I have done wickedly, woe unto me: if I have done righteously, I will not lift up mine head, being full of confusion, because I see mine affliction.
speaker: Narrator

text: But let it increase: hunt thou me as a lion: return and show thyself marvelous upon me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou renewest thy plagues against me, and thou increasest thy wrath against me: changes and armies of sorrows are against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore then hast thou brought me out of the womb? Oh that I had perished, and that none eye had seen me!
speaker: Narrator

text: And that I were as I had not been, but brought from the womb to the grave!
speaker: Narrator

text: Are not my days few? let him cease, and leave off from me, that I may take a little comfort,
speaker: Narrator

text: Before I go and shall not return, even to the land of darkness and shadow of death:
speaker: Narrator

text: Into a land, I say, dark as darkness itself, and into the shadow of death, where is none order, but the light is there as darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then answered Zophar the Naamathite, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Should not the multitude of words be answered? or should a great talker be justified?
speaker: Narrator

text: Should men hold their peace at thy lies? and when thou mockest others, shall none make thee ashamed?
speaker: Narrator

text: For thou hast said, My doctrine is pure, and I am clean in thine eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: But, oh that God would speak and open his lips against thee!
speaker: Narrator

text: That he might show thee the secrets of wisdom how thou hast deserved double, according to right: know therefore that God hath forgotten thee for thine iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Canst thou by searching find out God? canst thou find out the Almighty to his perfection?
speaker: Narrator

text: The heavens are high, what canst thou do? it is deeper than the hell, how canst thou know it?
speaker: Narrator

text: The measure thereof is longer than the earth, and it is broader than the Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he cut off and shut up, or gather together, who can turn him back?
speaker: Narrator

text: For he knoweth vain men, and seeth iniquity, and him that understandeth nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet vain man would be wise, though man newborn is like a wild ass colt.
speaker: Narrator

text: If thou prepare thine heart, and stretch out thine hands toward him:
speaker: Narrator

text: If iniquity be in thine hand, put it far away, and let no wickedness dwell in thy Tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then truly shalt thou lift up thy face without spot, and shalt be stable, and shalt not fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: But thou shalt forget thy misery, and remember it as waters that are past.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thine age also shall appear more clear than the noon day: thou shalt shine and be as the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: And thou shalt be bold, because there is hope: and thou shalt dig pits, and shalt lie down safely.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when thou takest thy rest, none shall make thee afraid: yea, many shall make suit unto thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the eyes of the wicked shall fail, and their refuge shall perish, and their hope shall be sorrow of mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed because that ye are the people only, wisdom must die with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have understanding as well as you, and am not inferior unto you: yea, who knoweth not such things?
speaker: Narrator

text: I am as one mocked of his neighbor, who calleth upon God, and he heareth him: the just and the upright is laughed to scorn.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that is ready to fall, is as a lamp despised in the opinion of the rich.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tabernacles of robbers do prosper, and they are in safety, that provoke God, whom God hath enriched with his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ask now the beasts, and they shall teach thee, and the fowls of the heaven, and they shall tell thee:
speaker: Narrator

text: Or speak to the earth, and it shall show thee: or the fishes of the sea, and they shall declare unto thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is ignorant of all these, but that the hand of the Lord hath made these?
speaker: Narrator

text: In whose hand is the soul of every living thing, and the breath of all mankind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth not the ears discern the words, and the mouth taste meat for itself?
speaker: Narrator

text: Among the ancient is wisdom, and in the length of days is understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: With him is wisdom and strength: he hath counsel and understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, he will break down, and it cannot be built: he shutteth a man up, and he cannot be loosed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, he withholdeth the waters, and they dry up: but when he sendeth them out, they destroy the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: With him is strength and wisdom: he that is deceived, and that deceiveth, are his.
speaker: Narrator

text: He causeth the counselors to go as spoiled, and maketh the judges fools.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looseth the collar of kings, and girdeth their loins with a girdle.
speaker: Narrator

text: He leadeth away the princes as a prey, and overthroweth the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: He taketh away the speech from the faithful counselors, and taketh away the judgment of the ancient.
speaker: Narrator

text: He poureth contempt upon princes, and maketh the strength of the mighty weak.
speaker: Narrator

text: He discovereth the deep places from their darkness, and bringeth forth the shadow of death to light.
speaker: Narrator

text: He increaseth the people, and destroyeth them: he enlargeth the nations, and bringeth them in again.
speaker: Narrator

text: He taketh away the hearts of them that are the chief over the people of the earth, and maketh them to wander in the wilderness out of the way.
speaker: Narrator

text: They grope in the dark without light: and he maketh them to stagger like a drunken man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, mine eye hath seen all this: mine ear hath heard, and understood it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know also as much as you know: I am not inferior unto you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will speak to the Almighty, and I desire to dispute with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For indeed ye forge lies, and all you are physicians of no value.
speaker: Narrator

text: Oh, that you would hold your tongue, that it might be imputed to you for wisdom!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now hear my disputation, and give ear to the arguments of my lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: Will ye speak wickedly for God’s defense, and talk deceitfully for his cause?
speaker: Narrator

text: Will ye accept his person? or will ye contend for God?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it well that he should seek of you? will you make a lie for him, as one lieth for a man?
speaker: Narrator

text: He will surely reprove you, if ye do secretly accept any person.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shall not his excellency make you afraid? and his fear fall upon you?
speaker: Narrator

text: Your memories may be compared unto ashes, and your bodies unto bodies of clay.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hold your tongues in my presence, that I may speak, and let come upon what will.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore do I take my flesh in my teeth, and put my soul in my hand?
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, though he slay me, yet will I trust in him, and I will reprove my ways in his sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall be my salvation also: for the hypocrite shall not come before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear diligently my words, and mark my talk.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold now: if I prepare me to judgment, I know that I shall be justified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is he that will plead with me? for if I now hold my tongue, I die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do not these two things unto me: then will I not hide myself from thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Withdraw thine hand from me, and let not thy fear make me afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then call thou, and I will answer: or let me speak, and answer thou me.
speaker: Narrator

text: How many are mine iniquities and sins, show me my rebellion and my sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore hidest thou thy face, and takest me for thine enemy?
speaker: Narrator

text: Wilt thou break a leaf driven to and fro? and wilt thou pursue the dry stubble?
speaker: Narrator

text: For thou writest bitter things against me, and makest me to possess the iniquities of my youth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou puttest my feet also in the stocks, and lookest narrowly unto all my paths, and makest the print thereof in the heels of my feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Such a one consumeth like a rotten thing, and as a garment that is moth-eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: Man that is born of woman, is of short continuance and full of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shooteth forth as a flower, and is cut down: he vanisheth also as a shadow, and continueth not.
speaker: Narrator

text: And yet thou openest thine eyes upon such one, and causest me to enter into judgment with thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who can bring a clean thing out of filthiness? there is not one.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are not his days determined? the number of his months are with thee: thou hast appointed his bound, which he cannot pass.
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn from him that he may cease until his desired day, as an hireling.
speaker: Narrator

text: For there is hope of a tree, if it be cut down, that it will yet sprout, and the branches thereof will not cease.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though the root of it wax old in the earth, and the stock thereof be dead in the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet by the scent of water it will bud, and bring forth boughs like a plant.
speaker: Narrator

text: But man is sick, and dieth, and man perisheth, and where is he?
speaker: Narrator

text: As the waters pass from the sea, and as the flood decayeth and drieth up,
speaker: Narrator

text: So man sleepeth and riseth not: for he shall not wake again, nor be raised from his sleep till the heaven be no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: Oh that thou wouldest hide me in the grave, and keep me secret, until thy wrath were past, and wouldest give me term, and remember me!
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man die, shall he live again? All the days of mine appointed time will I wait, till my changing shall come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou shalt call me, and I will answer thee: thou lovest the work of thine own hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now thou numberest my steps, and doest not delay my sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine iniquity is sealed up, as in a bag, and thou addest unto my wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: And surely as the mountain that falleth, cometh to nought, and the rock that is removed from his place:
speaker: Narrator

text: As the water breaketh the stones, when thou overflowest the things which grow in the dust of the earth: so thou destroyest the hope of man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou prevailest always against him, so that he passeth away: he changeth his face when thou castest him away.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he knoweth not if his sons shall be honorable, neither shall he understand concerning them, whether they shall be of low degree,
speaker: Narrator

text: But while his flesh is upon him, he shall be sorrowful, and while his soul is in him, it shall mourn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then answered Eliphaz the Temanite, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shall a wise man speak words of the wind? and fill his belly with the East wind?
speaker: Narrator

text: Shall he dispute with words not comely? or with talk that is not profitable?
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely thou hast cast off fear, and restrainest prayer before God:
speaker: Narrator

text: For thy mouth declareth thine iniquity, seeing thou hast chosen the tongue of the crafty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thine own mouth condemneth thee, and not I, and thy lips testify against thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Art thou the first man that was born? and wast thou made before the hills?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou heard the secret counsel of God, and dost thou restrain wisdom to thee?
speaker: Narrator

text: What knowest thou that we know not? and understandest that is not in us?
speaker: Narrator

text: With us are both ancient and very aged men, far older than thy father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seem the consolations of God small unto thee? is this thing strange unto thee?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why doth thine heart take thee away, and what do thine eyes mean,
speaker: Narrator

text: That thou answerest to God at thy pleasure, and bringest such words out of thy mouth?
speaker: Narrator

text: What is man, that he should be clean? and he that is born of woman, that he should be just?
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, he found no steadfastness in his Saints: yea, the heavens are not clean in his sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much more is man abominable, and filthy, which drinketh iniquity like water?
speaker: Narrator

text: I will tell thee: hear me, and I will declare that which I have seen:
speaker: Narrator

text: Which wise men have told, as they have heard of their fathers, and have not kept it secret:
speaker: Narrator

text: To whom alone the land was given, and no stranger passed through them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wicked man is continually as one that travaileth of child, and the number of years is hid from the tyrant.
speaker: Narrator

text: A sound of fear is in his ears, and in his prosperity the destroyer shall come upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He believeth not to return out of darkness: for he seeth the sword before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He wandereth to and fro for bread where he may: he knoweth that the day of darkness is prepared at hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Affliction and anguish shall make him afraid: they shall prevail against him as a king ready to the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he hath stretched out his hand against God, and made himself strong against the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore God shall run upon him, even upon his neck, and against the most thick part of his shield.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he hath covered his face with his fatness, and hath collops in his flank.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though he dwell in desolate cities, and in houses which no man inhabiteth, but are become heaps,
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall not be rich, neither shall his substance continue, neither shall he prolong the perfection thereof in the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall never depart out of darkness: the flame shall dry up his branches, and he shall go away with the breath of his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He believeth not that he erreth in vanity: therefore vanity shall be his change.
speaker: Narrator

text: His branch shall not be green, but shall be cut off before his day.
speaker: Narrator

text: God shall destroy him as the vine her sour grape, and shall cast him off, as the olive doth her flower.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the congregation of the hypocrite shall be desolate, and fire shall devour the houses of bribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they conceive mischief and bring forth vanity, and their belly hath prepared deceit.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Job answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: I have oftentimes heard such things: miserable comforters are ye all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shall there be none end of words of wind? or what maketh thee bold so to answer?
speaker: Narrator

text: I could also speak as ye do: (but would God your soul were in my soul’s stead) I could keep you company in speaking, and could shake mine head at you,
speaker: Narrator

text: But I would strengthen you with my mouth, and the comfort of my lips should assuage your sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though I speak, my sorrow cannot be assuaged: though I cease, what release have I?
speaker: Narrator

text: But now he maketh me weary: O God, thou hast made all my congregation desolate,
speaker: Narrator

text: And hast made me full of wrinkles which is a witness thereof, and my leanness riseth up in me, testifying the same in my face.
speaker: Narrator

text: His wrath hath torn me, and he hateth me, and gnasheth upon me with his teeth: mine enemy hath sharpened his eyes against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have opened their mouths upon me, and smitten me on the cheek in reproach: they gathered themselves together against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: God hath delivered me to the unjust, and hath made me to turn out of the way by the hands of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was in wealth, but he hath brought me to nought: he hath taken me by the neck and beaten me, and set me as a mark for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: His archers compass me round about: he cutteth my reins, and doth not spare, and poureth my gall upon the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath broken me with one breaking upon another, and runneth upon me like a giant.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have sowed a sackcloth upon my skin, and have abased mine horn unto the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text: My face is withered with weeping, and the shadow of death is upon mine eyes,
speaker: Narrator

text: Though there be no wickedness in mine hands, and my prayer be pure.
speaker: Narrator

text: O earth, cover not thou my blood, and let my crying find no place.
speaker: Narrator

text: For lo, now my witness is in the heaven, and my record is on high.
speaker: Narrator

text: My friends speak eloquently against me: but mine eye poureth out tears unto God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Oh that a man might plead with God, as man with his neighbor!
speaker: Narrator

text: For the years accounted come, and I shall go the way, whence I shall not return.
speaker: Narrator

text: My breath is corrupt: my days are cut off, and the grave is ready for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are none but mockers with me, and mine eye continueth in their bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lay down now, and put me in surety for thee: who is he, that will touch mine hand?
speaker: Narrator

text: For thou hast hid their heart from understanding: therefore shalt thou not set them up on high.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the eyes of his children shall fail, that speaketh flattery to his friends.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath also made me a byword of the people, and I am as a tabret before them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine eye therefore is dim for grief, and all my strength is like a shadow.
speaker: Narrator

text: The righteous shall be astonied at this, and the innocent shall be moved against the hypocrite.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the righteous will hold his way, and he whose hands are pure, shall increase his strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: All you therefore turn you, and come now, and I shall not find one wise among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: My days are past, mine enterprises are broken, and the thoughts of mine heart
speaker: Narrator

text: Have changed the night for the day, and the light that approached, for darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though I hope, yet the grave shall be mine house, and I shall make my bed in the dark.
speaker: Narrator

text: I shall say to corruption, Thou art my father, and to the worm, Thou art my mother and my sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where is then now mine hope? or who shall consider the thing that I hoped for?
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall go down into the bottom of the pit: surely it shall lie together in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: When will ye make an end of your words? cause us to understand, and then we will speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore are we counted as beasts, and are vile in your sight?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou art as one that teareth his soul in his anger. Shall the earth be forsaken for thy sake? or the rock removed out of his place?
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, the light of the wicked shall be quenched, and the spark of his fire shall not shine.
speaker: Narrator

text: The light shall be dark in his dwelling, and his candle shall be put out with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The steps of his strength shall be restrained, and his own counsel shall cast him down.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he is taken in the net by his feet, and he walketh upon the snares.
speaker: Narrator

text: The grenne shall take him by the heel, and the chief shall come upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: A snare is laid for him in the ground, and a trap for him in the way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fearfulness shall make him afraid on every side, and shall drive him to his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: His strength shall be famine: and destruction shall be ready at his side.
speaker: Narrator

text: It shall devour the inner parts of his skin, and the firstborn of death shall devour his strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: His hope shall be rooted out of his dwelling, and shall cause him to go to the king of fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear shall dwell in his house (because it is not his) and brimstone shall be scattered upon his habitation.
speaker: Narrator

text: His roots shall be dried up beneath, and above shall his branch be cut down.
speaker: Narrator

text: His remembrance shall perish from the earth, and he shall have no name in the street.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall drive him out of the light unto darkness, and chase him out of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall neither have son nor nephew among his people, nor any posterity in his dwellings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The posterity shall be astonied at his day, and fear shall come upon the ancient.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely such are the habitations of the wicked, and this is the place of him that knoweth not God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Job answered, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: How long will ye vex my soul, and torment me with words?
speaker: Narrator

text: Ye have now ten times reproached me, and are not ashamed: ye are impudent toward me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And though I had indeed erred, mine error remaineth with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But indeed if ye will advance yourselves against me, and rebuke me for my reproach,
speaker: Narrator

text: Know now, that God hath overthrown me, and hath compassed me with his net.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, I cry out of violence, but I have none answer: I cry, but there is no judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath hedged up my way that I cannot pass, and he hath set darkness in my paths.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath spoiled me of mine honor, and taken the crown away from mine head.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath destroyed me on every side, and I am gone: and he hath removed mine hope like a tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he hath kindled his wrath against me, and counteth me as one of his enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: His armies came together, and made their way upon me, and camped about my tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath removed my brethren far from me, and also mine acquaintance were strangers unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text: My neighbors have forsaken me, and my familiars have forgotten me.
speaker: Narrator

text: They that dwell in mine house, and my maids took me for a stranger: for I was a stranger in their sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: I called my servant, but he would not answer, though I prayed him with my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: My breath was strange unto my wife, though I prayed her for the children’s sake of mine own body.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wicked also despised me, and when I rose, they spake against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: All my secret friends abhorred me, and they whom I loved, are turned against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: My bone cleaveth to my skin and to my flesh, and I have escaped with the skin of my teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have pity upon me: have pity upon me, (O ye my friends) for the hand of God hath touched me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do ye persecute me, as God? and are not satisfied with my flesh?
speaker: Narrator

text: Oh that my words were now written! oh that they were written even in a book,
speaker: Narrator

text: And graven with an iron pen in lead, or in stone forever!
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am sure that my Redeemer liveth, and he shall stand the last on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And though after my skin worms destroy this body, yet shall I see God in my flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whom I myself shall see, and mine eyes shall behold, and none other for me, though my reins are consumed within me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But ye said, Why is he persecuted? And there was a deep matter in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be ye afraid of the sword: for the sword will be avenged of wickedness, that ye may know that there is a judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then answered Zophar the Naamathite, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Doubtless my thoughts cause me to answer, and therefore I make haste.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have heard the correction of my reproach: therefore the spirit of mine understanding causeth me to answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Knowest thou not this of old? and since God placed man upon the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: That the rejoicing of the wicked is short, and that the joy of the hypocrites is but a moment?
speaker: Narrator

text: Though his excellency mount up to the heaven, and his head reach unto the clouds,
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet shall he perish forever like his dung, and they which have seen him, shall say, Where is he?
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall flee away as a dream, and they shall not find him, and shall pass away as a vision of the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: So that the eye which had seen him, shall do so no more, and his place shall see him no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: His children shall flatter the poor, and his hands shall restore his substance.
speaker: Narrator

text: His bones are full of the sin of his youth, and it shall lie down with him in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text: When wickedness was sweet in his mouth, and he hid it under his tongue,
speaker: Narrator

text: And favored it, and would not forsake it, but kept it close in his mouth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his meat in his bowels was turned: the gall of Asps was in the midst of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath devoured substance, and he shall vomit it: for God shall draw it out of his belly.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall suck the gall of Asps, and the viper’s tongue shall slay him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall not see the rivers, nor the floods and streams of honey and butter.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall restore the labor, and shall devour no more: even according to the substance shall be his exchange, and he shall enjoy it no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he hath undone many: he hath forsaken the poor, and hath spoiled houses which he built not.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely he shall feel no quietness in his body, neither shall he reserve of that which he desired.
speaker: Narrator

text: There shall none of his meat be left: therefore none shall hope for his goods.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he shall be filled with his abundance, he shall be in pain, and the hand of all the wicked shall assail him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall be about to fill his belly, but God shall send upon him his fierce wrath, and shall cause to rain upon him, even upon his meat.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall flee from the iron weapons, and the bow of steel shall strike him through.
speaker: Narrator

text: The arrow is drawn out, and cometh forth of the body, and shineth of his gall, so fear cometh upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: All darkness shall be hid in his secret places: the fire that is not blown shall devour him, and that which remaineth in his tabernacle shall be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The heaven shall declare his wickedness, and the earth shall rise up against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The increase of his house shall go away: it shall flow away in the day of his wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the portion of the wicked man from God, and the heritage that he shall have of God, for his words.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Job answered, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear diligently my words, and this shall be instead of your consolations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suffer me that I may speak, and when I have spoken, mock on.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do I direct my talk to man? If it were so, how should not my spirit be troubled?
speaker: Narrator

text: Mark me, and be abashed, and lay your hand upon your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even when I remember, I am afraid, and fear taketh hold on my flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore do the wicked live, and wax old, and grow in wealth?
speaker: Narrator

text: Their seed is established in their sight with them, and their generation before their eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their houses are peaceable without fear, and the rod of God is not upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their bullock gendereth, and faileth not: their cow calveth, and casteth not her calf.
speaker: Narrator

text: They send forth their children like sheep, and their sons dance.
speaker: Narrator

text: They take the tambourine and harp, and rejoice in the sound of the organs.
speaker: Narrator

text: They spend their days in wealth, and suddenly they go down to the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text: They say also unto God, Depart from us: for we desire not the knowledge of thy ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is the Almighty, that we should serve him? and what profit should we have, if we should pray unto him?
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, their wealth is not in their hand: therefore let the counsel of the wicked be far from me.
speaker: Narrator

text: How oft shall the candle of the wicked be put out and their destruction come upon them? he will divide their lives in his wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall be as stubble before the wind, and as chaff that the storm carrieth away.
speaker: Narrator

text: God will lay up the sorrow of the father for his children: when he rewardeth him, he shall know it.
speaker: Narrator

text: His eyes shall see his destruction, and he shall drink of the wrath of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what pleasure hath he in his house after him, when the number of his months is cut off?
speaker: Narrator

text: Shall any teach God knowledge, who judgeth the highest things?
speaker: Narrator

text: One dieth in his full strength, being in all ease and prosperity.
speaker: Narrator

text: His breasts are full of milk, and his bones run full of marrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: And another dieth in the bitterness of his soul, and never eateth with pleasure.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall sleep both in the dust, and the worms shall cover them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, I know your thoughts, and the enterprises wherewith ye do me wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: For ye say, Where is the prince’s house? and where is the tabernacle of the wicked’s dwelling?
speaker: Narrator

text: May ye not ask them that go by the way? and ye cannot deny their signs.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the wicked is kept unto the day of destruction, and they shall be brought forth to the day of wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who shall declare his way to his face? and who shall reward him for that he hath done?
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet shall he be brought to the grave, and remain in the heap.
speaker: Narrator

text: The slimy valley shall be sweet unto him, and every man shall draw after him, as before him there were innumerable.
speaker: Narrator

text: How then comfort ye me in vain, seeing in your answer there remain but lies?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: May a man be profitable unto God, as he that is wise may be profitable to himself?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it anything unto the Almighty, that thou art righteous? or is it profitable to him, that thou makest thy ways upright?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it for fear of thee that he will accuse thee? or go with thee into judgment?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not thy wickedness great, and thine iniquities innumerable?
speaker: Narrator

text: For thou hast taken the pledge from thy brother for nought, and spoiled the clothes of the naked.
speaker: Narrator

text: To such as were weary, thou hast not given water to drink, and hast withdrawn bread from the hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the mighty man had the earth, and he that was in authority, dwelt in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast cast out widows empty, and the arms of the fatherless were broken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore snares are round about thee, and fear shall suddenly trouble thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or darkness that thou shouldest not see, and abundance of waters shall cover thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not God on high in the heaven? and behold the height of the stars how high they are.
speaker: Narrator

text: But thou sayest, How should God know? can he judge through the dark cloud?
speaker: Narrator

text: The clouds hide him that he cannot see, and he walketh in the circle of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou marked the way of the world, wherein wicked men have walked?
speaker: Narrator

text: Which were cut down before the time, whose foundation was as a river that overflowed:
speaker: Narrator

text: Which said unto God, Depart from us, and asked what the Almighty could do for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet he filled their houses with good things: but let the counsel of the wicked be far from me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The righteous shall see them, and shall rejoice, and the innocent shall laugh them to scorn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely our substance is hid: but the fire hath devoured the remnant of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore acquaint thyself, I pray thee, with him, and make peace: thereby thou shalt have prosperity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Receive, I pray thee, the law of his mouth, and lay up his words in thine heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: If thou return to the Almighty, thou shalt be built up, and thou shalt put iniquity far from thy tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou shalt lay up gold for dust, and the gold of Ophir, as the flints of the rivers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, the Almighty shall be thy defense, and thou shalt have plenty of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: And thou shalt then delight in the Almighty, and lift up thy face unto God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou shalt make thy prayer unto him, and he shall hear thee, and thou shalt render thy vows.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou shalt also decree a thing, and he shall establish it unto thee, and the light shall shine upon thy ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: When others are cast down, then shalt thou say, I am lifted up: and God shall save the humble person.
speaker: Narrator

text: The innocent shall deliver the island, and it shall be preserved by the pureness of thine hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Job answered, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Though my talk be this day in bitterness, and my plague greater than my groaning,
speaker: Narrator

text: Would God yet I knew how to find him, I would enter unto his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: I would plead the cause before him, and fill my mouth with arguments.
speaker: Narrator

text: I would know the words, that he would answer me, and would understand what he would say unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Would he plead against me with his great power? No, but he would put strength in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: There the righteous might reason with him, so I should be delivered forever from my Judge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, if I go to the East, he is not there: if to the West, yet I cannot perceive him:
speaker: Narrator

text: If to the North where he worketh, yet I cannot see him: he will hide himself in the South, and I cannot behold him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he knoweth my way, and trieth me, and I shall come forth like gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: My foot hath followed his steps: his way have I kept, and have not declined:
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither have I departed from the commandment of his lips, and I have esteemed the words of his mouth more than mine appointed food.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet he is in one mind, and who can turn him? yea, he doeth what his mind desireth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he will perform that which is decreed of me, and many such things are with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I am troubled at his presence, and in considering it, I am afraid of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God hath softened mine heart, and the Almighty hath troubled me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am not cut off in darkness, but he hath hid the darkness from my face.
speaker: Narrator

text: How should not the times be hid from the Almighty, seeing that they which know him, see not his days?
speaker: Narrator

text: Some remove the landmarks, that rob the flocks and feed thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: They lead away the ass of the fatherless, and take the widow’s ox to pledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: They make the poor to turn out of the way, so that the poor of the earth hide themselves together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, others as wild asses in the wilderness, go forth to their business, and rise early for a prey: the wilderness giveth him and his children food.
speaker: Narrator

text: They reap his provision in the field, but they gather the late vintage of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cause the naked to lodge without garment, and without covering in the cold.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are wet with the showers of the mountains, and they embrace the rock for want of a covering.
speaker: Narrator

text: They pluck the fatherless from the breast, and take the pledge of the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cause him to go naked without clothing, and take the gleaning from the hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text: They that make oil between their walls, and tread their winepresses, suffer thirst.
speaker: Narrator

text: Men cry out of the city, and the souls of the slain cry out: yet God doth not charge them with folly.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are they that abhor the light: they know not the ways thereof, nor continue in the paths thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: The murderer riseth early, and killeth the poor and the needy: and in the night he is as a thief.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eye also of the adulterer waiteth for the twilight, and saith, None eye shall see me, and disguiseth his face.
speaker: Narrator

text: They dig through houses in the dark, which they marked for themselves in the day: they know not the light.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the morning is even to them as the shadow of death: if one know them, they are in the terrors of the shadow of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is swift upon the waters: their portion shall be cursed in the earth: he will not behold the way of the vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the dry ground and heat consume the snow waters, so shall the grave the sinners.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pitiful man shall forget him: the worm shall feel his sweetness: he shall be no more remembered, and the wicked shall be broken like a tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: He doth evil entreat the barren that doth not bear, neither doeth he good to the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text: He draweth also the mighty by his power, and when he riseth up, none is sure of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though men give him assurance to be in safety, yet his eyes are upon their ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are exalted for a little, but they are gone, and are brought low as all others: they are destroyed, and cut off as the top of an ear of corn.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if it be not so, where is he? or who will prove me a liar, and make my words of no value?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Power and fear is with him, that maketh peace in his places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is there any number in his armies? and upon whom shall not his light arise?
speaker: Narrator

text: And how may a man be justified with God? or how can he be clean that is born of woman?
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, he will give no light to the Moon, and the Stars are unclean in his sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much more man, a worm, even the son of man, which is but a worm?
speaker: Narrator

text: But Job answered, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Whom helpest thou? him that hath no power? savest thou the arm that hath no strength?
speaker: Narrator

text: Whom counselest thou? him that hath no wisdom? thou showest right well as the thing is.
speaker: Narrator

text: To whom dost thou declare these words? or whose spirit cometh out of thee?
speaker: Narrator

text: The dead things are formed under the waters, and near unto them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The grave is naked before him, and there is no covering for destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stretcheth out the North over the empty place, and hangeth the earth upon nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He bindeth the waters in his clouds, and the cloud is not broken under them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He holdeth back the face of his throne, and spreadeth his cloud upon it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath set bounds about the waters, until the day and night come to an end.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pillars of heaven tremble and quake at his reproof.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sea is calm by his power, and by his understanding he smiteth the pride thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: His Spirit hath garnished the heavens, and his hand hath formed the crooked serpent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, these are part of his ways: but how little a portion hear we of him? and who can understand his fearful power?
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover Job proceeded and continued his parable, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: The living God hath taken away my judgment: for the Almighty hath put my soul in bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet so long as my breath is in me, and the Spirit of God in my nostrils,
speaker: Narrator

text: My lips surely shall speak no wickedness, and my tongue shall utter no deceit.
speaker: Narrator

text: God forbid, that I should justify you: until I die, I will never take away mine innocency from myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will keep my righteousness, and will not forsake it: mine heart shall not reprove me of my days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine enemy shall be as the wicked, and he that riseth against me, as the unrighteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what hope hath the hypocrite when he hath heaped up riches, if God take away his soul?
speaker: Narrator

text: Will God hear his cry, when trouble cometh upon him?
speaker: Narrator

text: Will he set his delight on the Almighty? will he call upon God at all times?
speaker: Narrator

text: I will teach you what is in the hand of God, and I will not conceal that which is with the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, all ye yourselves have seen it: why then do you thus vanish vanity?
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the portion of a wicked man with God, and the heritage of tyrants, which they shall receive of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: If his children be in great number, the sword shall destroy them, and his posterity shall not be satisfied with bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: His remnant shall be buried in death, and his widows shall not weep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though he should heap up silver as the dust, and prepare raiment as the clay,
speaker: Narrator

text: He may prepare it, but the just shall put it on, and the innocent shall divide the silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: He buildeth his house as the moth, and as a lodge that the watchman maketh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the rich man sleepeth, he shall not be gathered to his fathers: they opened their eyes, and he was gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Terrors shall take him as waters, and a tempest shall carry him away by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: The East wind shall take him away, and he shall depart: and it shall hurl him out of his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God shall cast upon him and not spare, though he would fain flee out of his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every man shall clap their hands at him, and hiss at him out of their place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The silver surely hath his vein, and the gold his palace, where they take it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Iron is taken out of the dust, and brass is molten out of the stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: God putteth an end to darkness, and he trieth the perfection of all things: he setteth a bond of darkness, and of the shadow of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flood breaketh out against the inhabitant, and the waters forgotten of the foot, being higher than man, are gone away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of the same earth cometh bread, and under it, as it were fire is turned up.
speaker: Narrator

text: The stones thereof are a place of Sapphires, and the dust of it is gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a path which no fowl hath known, neither hath the kite’s eye seen it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lion’s whelps have not walked it, nor the Lion passed thereby.
speaker: Narrator

text: He putteth his hand upon the rocks, and overthroweth the mountains by the roots.
speaker: Narrator

text: He breaketh rivers in the roots, and his eye seeth every precious thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He bindeth the floods, that they do not overflow, and the thing that is hid, bringeth he to light.
speaker: Narrator

text: But where is wisdom found? and where is the place of understanding?
speaker: Narrator

text: Man knoweth not the price thereof: for it is not found in the land of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: The depth saith, It is not in me: the Sea also saith, It is not with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gold shall not be given for it, neither shall silver be weighed for the price thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: It shall not be valued with the wedge of gold of Ophir, nor with the precious onyx, nor the sapphire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gold nor the crystal shall be equal unto it, nor the exchange shall be for plate of fine gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: No mention shall be made of coral, nor of the gabish: for wisdom is more precious than pearls.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Topaz of Ethiopia shall not be equal unto it, neither shall it be valued with the wedge of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whence then cometh wisdom? and where is the place of understanding,
speaker: Narrator

text: Seeing it is hid from the eyes of all the living, and is hid from the fowls of the heaven?
speaker: Narrator

text: Destruction and death say, We have heard the fame thereof with our ears.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God understandeth the way thereof, and he knoweth the place thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he beholdeth the ends of the world, and seeth all that is under heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text: To make the weight of the winds and to weigh the waters by measure.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he made a decree for the rain, and a way for the lightning of the thunders,
speaker: Narrator

text: Then did he see it, and counted it: he prepared it, and also considered it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And unto man he said, Behold, the fear of the Lord is wisdom, and to depart from evil is understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Job proceeded, and continued his parable, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: Oh that I were as in times past, when God preserved me!
speaker: Narrator

text: When his light shined upon mine head: and when by his light I walked through the darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text: As I was in the days of my youth: when God’s providence was upon my tabernacle:
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Almighty was yet with me, and my children round about me:
speaker: Narrator

text: when I washed my paths with butter, and when the rock poured me out rivers of oil:
speaker: Narrator

text: When I went out to the gate, even to the judgment seat, and when I caused them to prepare my seat in the street.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young men saw me, and hid themselves, and the aged arose, and stood up.
speaker: Narrator

text: The princes stayed talk, and laid their hand on their mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The voice of princes was hid, and their tongue cleaved to the roof of their mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the ear heard me, it blessed me, and when the eye saw me, it gave witness to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I delivered the poor that cried, and the fatherless, and him that had none to help him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The blessing of him that was ready to perish, came upon me, and I caused the widow’s heart to rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text: I put on justice, and it covered me: my judgment was as a robe, and a crown.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was the eyes to the blind, and I was the feet to the lame.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was a father unto the poor, and when I knew not the cause, I sought it out diligently.
speaker: Narrator

text: I brake also the jaws of the unrighteous man, and plucked the prey out of his teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said, I shall die in my nest, and I shall multiply my days as the sand.
speaker: Narrator

text: For my root is spread out by the water, and the dew shall lie upon my branch.
speaker: Narrator

text: My glory shall renew toward me, and my bow shall be restored in mine hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Unto me men gave ear, and waited, and held their tongue at my counsel.
speaker: Narrator

text: After my words they replied not, and my talk dropped upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they waited for me, as for the rain, and they opened their mouth as for the latter rain.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I laughed on them, they believed it not: neither did they cause the light of my countenance to fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: I appointed out their way, and did sit as chief, and dwelt as a King in the army, and like him that comforteth the mourners.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now they that are younger than I, mock me: yea, they whose fathers I have refused to set with the dogs of my flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: For whereto should the strength of their hands have served me, seeing age perished in them?
speaker: Narrator

text: For poverty and famine they were solitary, fleeing into the wilderness, which is dark, desolate and waste.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cut up nettles by the bushes, and the juniper roots was their meat.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were chased forth from among men: they shouted at them, as at a thief.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore they dwelt in the clefts of rivers, in the holes of the earth and rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: They roared among the bushes, and under the thistles they gathered themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were the children of fools, and the children of villains, which were more vile than the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now am I their song, and I am their talk.
speaker: Narrator

text: They abhor me, and flee far from me, and spare not to spit in my face.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because that God hath loosed my cord and humbled me, they have loosed the bridle before me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The youth rise up at my right hand: they have pushed my feet, and have trode on me as on the paths of their destruction.
