speaker: Narrator

text: They have destroyed my paths: they took pleasure at my calamity, they had no help.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came as a great breach of waters, and under this calamity they come on heaps.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear is turned upon me: and they pursue my soul as the wind, and mine health passeth away as a cloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore my soul is now poured out upon me, and the days of affliction have taken hold on me.
speaker: Narrator

text: It pierceth my bones in the night, and my sinews take no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the great vehemency is my garments changed, which compasseth me about, as the collar of my coat.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath cast me into the mire, and I am become like ashes and dust.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I cry unto thee, thou dost not hear me, neither regardest me, when I stand up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou turnest thyself cruelly against me, and art enemy unto me with the strength of thine hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou takest me up and causest me to ride upon the wind, and makest my strength to fail.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely I know that thou wilt bring me to death, and to the house appointed for all the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: Doubtless none can stretch his hand unto the grave, though they cry in his destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Did not I weep with him that was in trouble? was not my soul in heaviness for the poor?
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet when I looked for good, evil came unto me: and when I waited for light, there came darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: My bowels did boil without rest: for the days of affliction are come upon me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I went mourning without sun: I stood up in the Congregation and cried.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am a brother to the Dragons, and a companion to the Ostriches.
speaker: Narrator

text: My skin is black upon me, and my bones are burnt with heat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore mine harp is turned to mourning, and mine organs into the voice of them that weep.
speaker: Narrator

text: I made a covenant with mine eyes: why then should I think on a maid?
speaker: Narrator

text: For what portion should I have of God from above? and what inheritance of the almighty from on high?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not destruction to the wicked, and strange punishment to the workers of iniquity?
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth not he behold my ways, and tell all my steps?
speaker: Narrator

text: If I have walked in vanity, or if my foot hath made haste to deceit?
speaker: Narrator

text: Let God weigh me in the just balance, and he shall know my uprightness.
speaker: Narrator

text: If my step hath turned out of the way, or mine heart hath walked after mine eye, or if any blot hath cleaved to mine hands,
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me sow, and let another eat: yea, let my plants be rooted out.
speaker: Narrator

text: If mine heart hath been deceived by a woman, or if I have laid wait at the door of my neighbor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Let my wife grind unto another man, and let other men bow down upon her.

Let thistles grow instead of wheat, and cockle in the stead of barley.
THE WORDS OF JOB ARE ENDED.
speaker: Narrator

text: So these three men ceased to answer Job, because he esteemed himself just.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the wrath of Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, was kindled: his wrath, I say, was kindled against Job, because he justified himself more than God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also his anger was kindled against his three friends, because they could not find an answer, and yet condemned Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now Elihu had waited till Job had spoken: for they were more ancient in years than he.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So when Elihu saw, that there was none answer in the mouth of the three men, his wrath was kindled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Elihu the son of Barachel, the Buzite answered and said, I am young in years, and ye are ancient: therefore I doubted, and was afraid to show you mine opinion.

text: Which leaveth his eggs in the earth, and maketh them hot in the dust,
speaker: Narrator

text: And forgetteth that the foot might scatter them, or that the wild beast might break them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He showeth himself cruel unto his young ones, as they were not his, and is without fear, as if he travailed in vain.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God had deprived him of wisdom, and hath given him no part of understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: When time is, he mounteth on high: he mocketh the horse and his rider.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou given the horse strength, or covered his neck with neighing?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou made him afraid as the grasshopper? his strong neighing is fearful.
speaker: Narrator

text: He diggeth in the valley, and rejoiceth in his strength: he goeth forth to meet the harnessed man.
speaker: Narrator

text: He mocketh at fear, and is not afraid, and turneth not back from the sword,
speaker: Narrator

text: Though the quiver rattle against him, the glittering spear and the shield.
speaker: Narrator

text: He swalloweth the ground for fierceness and rage, and he believeth not that it is the noise of the trumpet.
speaker: Narrator

text: He saith among the trumpets, Ha, ha: he smelleth the battle afar off, and the noise of the captains, and the shouting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shall the hawk fly by thy wisdom, stretching out his wings even toward the South?
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth the eagle mount up at thy commandment, or make his nest on high?
speaker: Narrator

text: She abideth and remaineth in the rock, even upon the top of the rock, and the tower,
speaker: Narrator

text: From thence she spieth for meat, and her eyes behold afar off.
speaker: Narrator

text: His young ones also suck up blood: and where the slain are, there is she.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover the Lord spake unto Job, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Is this to learn, to strive with the Almighty? he that reproveth God, let him answer to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered the Lord, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, I am vile: what shall I answer thee? I will lay mine hand upon my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once have I spoken, but I will answer no more, yea twice, but I will proceed no further.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the Lord answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gird up now thy loins like a man: I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wilt thou disannul my judgment? or wilt thou condemn me, that thou mayest be justified?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or hast thou an arm like God? or dost thou thunder with a voice like him?
speaker: Narrator

text: Deck thyself now with majesty and excellency, and array thyself with beauty and glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cast abroad the indignation of thy wrath, and behold everyone that is proud, and abase him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look on everyone that is arrogant, and bring him low: and destroy the wicked in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hide them in the dust together, and bind their faces in a secret place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then will I confess unto thee also, that thy right hand can save thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold now Behemoth (whom I made with thee) which eateth grass as an ox.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold now, his strength is in his loins, and his force is in the navel of his belly.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he taketh pleasure, his tail is like a cedar: the sinews of his stones are wrapped together.
speaker: Narrator

text: His bones are like staves of brass, and his small bones like staves of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is the chief of the ways of God: he that made him, will make his sword to approach unto him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely the mountains bring him forth grass, where all the beasts of the field play.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lieth he under the trees in the covert of the reed and fens?
speaker: Narrator

text: Can the trees cover him with their shadow? or can the willows of the river compass him about?
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, he spoileth the river, and hasteth not: he trusteth that he can draw up Jordan into his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He taketh it with his eyes, and thrusteth his nose through whatsoever meeteth him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Canst thou draw out Leviathan with an hook, and with a line which thou shalt cast down unto his tongue?
speaker: Narrator

text: Canst thou cast an hook into his nose? canst thou pierce his jaws with an angle?
speaker: Narrator

text: Will he make many prayers unto thee? and speak thee fair?
speaker: Narrator

text: Will he make a covenant with thee? and wilt thou take him as a servant forever?
speaker: Narrator

text: Wilt thou play with him as with a bird? or wilt thou bind him for thy maids?
speaker: Narrator

text: Shall the companions banquet with him? shall they divide him among the merchants?
speaker: Narrator

text: Canst thou fill the basket with his skin? or the fishpanier with his head?
speaker: Narrator

text: Lay thine hand upon him: remember the battle, and do no more so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, his hope is in vain: for shall not one perish even at the sight of him?
speaker: Narrator

text: None is so fierce that dare stir him up. Who is he then that can stand before me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who hath prevented me that I should make an end? All under heaven is mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will not keep silence concerning his parts, nor his power, nor his comely proportion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who can discover the face of his garment? or who shall come to him with a double bridle?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who shall open the doors of his face? his teeth are fearful round about.
speaker: Narrator

text: The majesty of his scales is like strong shields, and are sure sealed.
speaker: Narrator

text: One is set to another, that no wind can come between them.
speaker: Narrator

text: One is joined to another: they stick together, that they cannot be sundered.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sneezings make the light to shine, and his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of his mouth go lamps, and sparks of fire leap out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of his nostrils cometh out smoke, as out of a boiling pot or caldron.
speaker: Narrator

text: His breath maketh the coals burn: for a flame goeth out of his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his neck remaineth strength, and labor is rejected before his face.
speaker: Narrator

text: The members of his body are joined: they are strong in themselves, and cannot be moved.
speaker: Narrator

text: His heart is as strong as a stone, and as hard as the nether millstone.
speaker: Narrator

text: The mighty are afraid of his majesty, and for fear they faint in themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sword doth touch him, he will not rise up, nor for the spear, dart nor habergeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: He esteemeth iron as straw, and brass as rotten wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The archer cannot make him flee: the stones of the sling are turneth into stubble unto him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The darts are counted as straw: and he laugheth at the shaking of the spear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sharp stones are under him, and he spreadeth sharp things upon the mire.
speaker: Narrator

text: He maketh the depth to boil like a pot, and maketh the Sea like a pot of ointment.
speaker: Narrator

text: He maketh a path to shine after him, one would think the depth as an hoar head.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the earth there is none like him: he is made without fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: He beholdeth all high things: he is a King over all the children of pride.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered the Lord, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: I know that thou canst do all things, and that there is no thought hid from thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is he that hideth counsel without knowledge? therefore have I spoken that I understood not, even things too wonderful for me, and which I knew not.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear, I beseech thee, and I will speak: I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have heard of thee by the hearing of the ear, but now mine eye seeth thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I abhor myself, and repent in dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now after that the Lord had spoken these words unto Job, the Lord also said unto Eliphaz the Temanite, My wrath is kindled against thee and against thy two friends: for ye have not spoken of me the thing that is right, like my servant Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore take unto you now seven bullocks, and seven rams, and go to my servant Job, and offer up for yourselves a burnt offering, and my servant Job shall pray for you: for I will accept him, lest I should put you to shame, because ye have not spoken of me the thing which is right, like my servant Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite, went, and did according as the Lord had said unto them, and the Lord accepted Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord turned the captivity of Job, when he prayed for his friends: also the Lord gave Job twice so much as he had before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then came unto him all his brethren, and all his sisters, and all they that had been of his acquaintance before, and did eat bread with him in his house, and had compassion on him, and comforted him for all the evil that the Lord had brought upon him, and every man gave him a piece of money, and everyone an earring of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord blessed the last days of Job more than the first: for he had fourteen thousand sheep, and six thousand camels, and a thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand she asses.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had also seven sons, and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he called the name of one Jemimah, and the name of the second Keziah, and the name of the third Keren-Happuch.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all the land were no women found so fair as the daughters of Job, and their father gave them inheritance among their brethren.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after this lived Job an hundred and forty years, and saw his sons, and his son’s sons, even four generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Job died, being old, and full of days.
speaker: Narrator
